div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 268px; height: 1px; padding-top: 224px; margin-left: 532px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 14px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
If there is no Intermediate CA setup as an environment variable or in a particular file location for the applications then the Intermediate CA creation process is called.
In order to create a new Intermediate CA the script will now check for the existence of a valid Root CA.
If there is no valid Root CA stored on the local filesystem - a new Root CA will be created.
With the Root CA validated the Intermediate CA creation process is called.
Once the Intermediate CA has been validated the Application Leaf Certificate process can commence.

switch.text: If there is no Intermediate CA setup a...

div.span: is executed on the bootstrapping platform to initialise all Root and Intermediate certificates required for the various lab components for my chosen applications or domain.

div.span: is used to generate the Leaf Certificates for the Public Internet facing interfaces of my websites.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 776px; height: 1px; padding-top: 885px; margin-left: 15px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 14px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
CLI:
<Insert Name Here>--cli.pem, <Insert Name Here>--cli-key.pem, <Insert Name Here>--cli.csr
Client/Peer:
<Insert Name Here>--peer.pem, <Insert Name Here>--peer-key.pem, <Insert Name Here>--peer.csr
Server:
<Insert Name Here>--server.pem, <Insert Name Here>--server-key.pem, <Insert Name Here>--server.csr
Example applications
- consul : Service Mesh, Service Discovery, Key Value Store
- vault : Centralised Secret Management
- nomad : Scheduler
- ssh : Internal SSH CA
- bastion :

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 476px; height: 1px; padding-top: 106px; margin-left: 16px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 14px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;

div.div:
The Root CA for my lab and domain Hashistack.ie is generated using the script, Generate_PKI_for_my_Lab.sh, which is hosted on a vagrant VM on my laptop. In a production environment this should NOT be internet connected whenever possible. The Root CA is YOUR SECRET ZERO - Protect it!
Certificate configuration directory:
/usr/local/bootstrap/conf/certificates
Root CA Path:
/usr/local/bootstrap/.bootstrap/Outputs/RootCA/
Private Key:
hashistack-root-ca-key.pem
Public Certificate:
hashistack-root-ca.pem
MacOS Browser Package:
hashistack-root-ca.pem-cert.p12
This Root CA should be used to sign the Intermediate CAs. The idea behind this being that if an Intermediate signing key is compromised the blast radius is minimised to only those certificates signed by the compromised CA.
The Root CA should be stored somewhere offline and secure when not in use.

switch.text: The Root CA for my lab and domain Hashistack.ie is generated using t...

div.div:
The Certbot binary from Let’s Encrypt is used to manually request a new certificate on the initial request.
Subsequent requests should not require and manual steps...I hope.
